Thankfully Leslie intervened before things got out of hand; stepping between me and the cabana boy. “Okay, I think that’s enough for one day, sweetie.” Turning to the cabana boy, she said. “I’m sorry about my friend; she’s a bit over-served."

The cabana boy beat a hasty retreat while Leslie pulled me away from the pool. “W-Wha’s going on?” slurring a little bit, I said, “Wha’s the big idea?”

Once we were in private, Leslie looked at me and said, “How much did you have to drink?”

“I only had too mo-hoo-toes.”

“Okay, well there are three things you need to know: One, you can’t handle your liquor. Two, you’ve got no game at all. And three, acting like that at a family pool is a very good way to get yourself removed from the hotel."

"Ouch. I think I need a little help."

“Let’s get you upstairs to your room; you take a nap, then we’ll get you some coffee, and then I’ll teach you how to flirt.”

Even in my inebriated state, I found the idea of Leslie teaching me to flirt hilarious. “You?”

Giving me one of those ‘are you kidding me’ looks, Leslie said, “Just because I’ve put on an extra 20 pounds, doesn’t mean I can’t get people to look at me.” Grabbing my hand, Leslie said, “I’ll show you tonight after you’ve sobered up?”
1111111113111111111111.title: After the Spa

11111111131111111111111.content:
I woke up from my nap feeling a lot better than I had earlier. As I sat in bed, I had a vague recollection of what happened at the pool. I couldn't believe that I almost got naked in front of children. I was grateful that Leslie had stepped in when she did. Getting out of bed, I walked into the next room to find Leslie sitting on the couch reading a book of baby names. “Still trying to settle on a name for the baby?”

“Yeah; one minute I have a name I like, but then the next minute I hate it.” Sighing, as she put the book down, Leslie said, “At first I wanted to name the baby Theodore, after the man I used to be; but then I realized he didn’t deserve that honor. With two months until he’s born, I’m running out of time.”

“When me and...sorry, when Kevin and Kelsey were born, their parents waited until the last minute to decide on a name.” taking a seat next to Leslie, I said, “If I might make a suggestion, how about Kyle David?”

“What made you think of those names?” then it hit her, as she was looking at me. “Oh right, those were your friend’s names.”

“Does it ever get easier?” Sitting back on the couch, I said, “Will I ever be able to think of Kevin as being a different person than who I am now?”

“It does get easier as time goes by, but it never really goes away.” Looking at me, smiling, Leslie said, “Just think of Kevin’s life as the impetus for your life as Amelia.”

The more I thought about it, the more I realized Leslie was right. Failing to acknowledge Kevin’s role in my new life would be a horrible idea. “I’ll have to keep that in mind.” Smiling, I said, “Now back to that name idea; what do you think?”

“Kyle David Cummings; I like how it just rolls off the tongue.” Checking her phone, Leslie said, “Hurry up and get changed, we’re going out to the club; that way I can show you how to flirt.”

I couldn’t help but laugh at the idea of Leslie teaching me how to flirt. “I’m sorry, but I still can’t see you teaching me how to flirt.” Pausing, I said, “Once anyone, man or woman, sees that wedding ring and your belly they’ll lose interest.”

“Trust me; I think you’ll change your mind after tonight.” Getting to her feet, Leslie said, “Now come on, go get changed; I left a dress hanging in the bathroom for you.”
11111111131111111111111.title: Waking Up Sober

111111111311111111111111.content:
The dress that Leslie left for me was pretty much what one would consider a little black dress. It was clingy in all the right places and even lifted my breasts ever so slightly. As I stood in front of the bathroom mirror, looking at my reflection, I couldn’t stop thinking about much things had changed in such a short time. I’d gone from being an unhappy teenage boy to a woman in her 20s; one who was being taken to a bar to learn how to flirt with guys.

After touching up my makeup, I carefully got into the heeled boots that Leslie left for me. I was worried about walking in them but found that I had no problem doing so. Then I remembered they’d given me that knowledge. Walking out into the main room, I saw Leslie talking on her phone. “We should be at the bar shortly; I’m just waiting on Amelia.” Seeing me in the doorway, she said, “I gotta go, she’s standing in the doorway.”

Once Leslie hung up her phone, I said, “Who were you talking to?”

“That would be my wife, Grace.” Putting her phone away, Leslie said, “She’s going to meet us at the bar.”

As I followed Leslie towards the door, I said, “That’s great, I can’t wait to meet her.” Stopping mid-stride, I said, “Wait, does she know about me?”

“Just the basics; you were a teenage boy but now you’re a woman.” Opening the door, Leslie said, “I figured you’d want to tell her the rest.”

Walking out the door, with a grin, I said, “Maybe I’ll tell her how you’ve been practically flirting with me all day.”

“Honey, please; you’d know if I was flirting with you.” Walking down the hall, Leslie said, “That reminds me, you’re going to get a lot of attention in that outfit; good and bad. So be prepared.”

“Is that why you picked it for me to wear?”

“Pretty much; I wanted you to get used to people taking an interest in you.” With a grin, Leslie said, “Besides, it doesn’t hurt that you look amazing in it.”

*********************************


Leslie was right; I was getting a lot of attention because of my outfit. It was still weird to think this was my life now; I wondered
how these folks would react if they learned that the woman they were flirting with used to be a teenage boy.

We’d been at the bar for almost 25 minutes; Leslie was sitting at a nearby booth, while I was sitting up at the bar. I was sipping a bottle of Mike’s Hard Lemonade when a guy, a few years younger than myself, walked over. “Hey gorgeous, what’s a lovely lady like yourself doing here all alone?”

I know I’m a novice at flirting, but even I knew those pick up lines were dated. Deciding to play along, I said, “I’m here with a friend of mine; just trying to experience the local nightlife.”

“Perhaps you and your friend would like to come back to my place; my buddies and I could show you a good time.”

Something about the way he said that made me feel uneasy. Before I could rebuff him, however, Leslie appeared next to me and said, “Girl, there you are; I’ve been looking all over for you.”

The guy took one look at Leslie’s belly and walked off. Taking my drink back to the table, I said, “Thanks for that; I got a weird vibe from that guy.”

“I heard him talking to some of his friends; good thing too because I think they planned on taking advantage of you.”

Taking a seat, I said, “Are all guys going to be like that?”

“As someone who used to be like these guys, I can tell you; there will be some who you’ll want to stay away from.” Sighing, Leslie said, “But there are good guys out there as well; you just have to find the right one.”

“That reminds me; weren’t you supposed to teach me about flirting?”

“I suppose now’s as good a time as any.” Pointing towards the bar, Leslie said, “You see that girl at the end; the one with the tattoos on her right arm?

Looking where Leslie was pointing, I saw a girl sitting at the bar no more than 5 feet away from us. Turning back to Leslie, I said, “I don’t know; I’m not sure she’s your type.”

Without saying a word, Leslie got up and walked over to the girl. It was just quiet enough that I could make out what they were saying. Looking at the girl, Leslie said, “I’ve been watching you from my booth; I think you’re one of the most beautiful women I’ve ever seen.”

“You’re not too bad yourself.” Smiling, the girl said, “Do you live in town?”

“No, but I don’t live that far from here.” Leaning closer, Leslie said, “What do you say we go back to my place?”

I was riveted by the scene before me; to my surprise, Leslie was having luck with a woman. I couldn’t help but feel sorry for the woman at the bar, though; I don’t think she realized that Leslie was married.

“I was just going to ask you the same thing; how about we go to my place instead.”

What came next was a complete surprise to me; as Leslie said, “Well then, I’m glad it’s the same place then.” Leaning forward to
kiss the woman, Leslie said, “Perhaps we can have a little fun tonight?”

I wasn’t sure what was going on; I was in shock as Leslie and the woman came over to the table. Looking at me, the woman said,
“I think we owe her an explanation, babe.”

Gesturing to the woman next to her, Leslie said, “Amelia; this is my wife, Grace.”
111111111311111111111111.title: At the Bar

1111111113111111111111111.content:
After introductions were made, the three of us sat down for some drinks; I had another Mike’s, Grace had a beer and Leslie had water. We stayed for a while until the bar got a little rowdy for our tastes, so we went back to my hotel room.

Leslie decided to lie down shortly after we got back to the room; so that left me alone with Grace. After changing out of the dress, I walked out into the bedroom to find Grace lying on the bed next to Leslie. Seeing the way she was around her, I could tell that Grace cared deeply for Leslie. Walking over to her, I said, “How about we grab a couple of beers and go chat on the balcony.”

Gently climbing out of bed, so as not to wake Leslie, Grace said, “Honey, you read my mind.”

With the beers in hand, the two of us adjourned to the balcony. As we sat down, I looked at Grace and said, “Leslie was rather tight-lipped about your life; if it’s alright, I’d like to hear it.”

“It won’t be nearly as interesting as yours, but I’ll do what I can.” Sipping the beer, Grace said, “I’m the 2nd oldest of four kids and the only girl. My dad served in the Army, go figure, so we moved around a lot. I was never really in one place long enough to make friends, so I hung out with my brothers.”

So that’s how Grace and I spent the next 30 minutes; talking about her childhood and how she and her siblings all joined the military. The more she talked, the more I got the sense that she strongly disliked those who attacked someone for their religion or sexual orientation. Which had me wondering why she was married to someone like Leslie? Taking a sip from my beer, I said, “Forgive me if I’m out of line here, but I can’t figure out exactly why you’re married to someone like Leslie.” Pausing, I said, “Don’t get me wrong, she’s a wonderful person now; but in her former life she would’ve been vehemently anti-homosexual.”

“Believe me; when I found out the truth, about who she used to be, I considered just ending the date then and there. The last thing I wanted to do was date a formerly bigoted middle-aged man.”

“What changed your mind?”

“I spoke with Heather, the mutual friend who set us up. She assured me that Leslie’s desire to change was genuine; that she wanted to experience the type of life that her daughter was living.” Leaning back in the chair, Grace said, “So I took a chance and asked her on a second date. I’m glad that I did; forgive the corniness, but she’s the love of my life. When the time comes for her daughter to learn the truth, I hope she sees that Leslie has changed for the better.”

Until that moment I hadn’t given much thought to how Kelsey and my mom would respond to me becoming a woman. “It’s funny you mention that because I’m rather worried about how my family will react when they learn that I’ve become a woman.” Sighing, I said, “All this was their idea so, deep down, I hope they’ll be supportive.”

“I wasn’t going to ask this; but since you brought it up.” Leaning forward, Grace said, “What was so wrong with your old life that your mother and sister thought this would be a good idea?”

“Ever since I turned 13, I’ve just been unhappy; just going through the day to day motions.” Taking a breath, I said, “Don’t get me wrong, there were moments where I was happy, but they were few and far between.”

“Forgive me if I’m off base, but going to a place like New Horizons seems just a tiny bit drastic.” Sighing, Grace said, “I was still trying to figure out whether or not I was straight at your age. There were certainly times where I got depressed, but I don’t think I would’ve gone to the lengths that you went to.”

“Well there’s no turning back now, so I guess I’m stuck with the consequences of my decision.” Pausing, I said, “Just out of
curiosity, when exactly did you figure it out?”

It took a moment for Grace to realize what I was getting at; but once she did, she sighed and said, “About a year after I enlisted I found myself alone in the base gym when this girl from my unit, a recent recruit, walked in.” pausing, Grace said, “We got to talking; long story short, we ended up dating for two years.”

“You’re no longer together, so what happened?”

“It turns out that I was a lesbian, but she wasn’t.” taking a deep, labored breath Grace said, “She thought she was, but she figured out about 3 months into our relationship that she wasn’t. Rather than come clean right then and there, she led me on for another 15 months. Last I heard she was working as a teacher in Seattle with her husband.”

“It seems to me like things worked out well in the end; you’re married to Leslie and you’re about to have a child together.”

****************************


We talked for a little while longer until I mentioned what happened with the guy at the bar. “I’m still new to all this, so I have no clue how to figure out whether or not a guy is a creep.” Sighing, I said, “If it hadn’t been for Leslie stepping in, I probably would have left with the guy.”

“Oh please, I would’ve intervened before it got to that point.” Getting up, Grace said, “But if you’re interested, I can teach you some self-defense moves.”

Despite everything I’d learned about her, I had some misgivings about Grace teaching me. Looking at her, I said, “Grace, I’m 130lbs soaking wet; I doubt there’s much I can do to defend myself.”

“I served in the Army for 4 years, and had 3 brothers trust me when I say I can show you some things.”

And that’s what we were doing when Leslie walked out onto the patio; Grace was on her knees and I had her arm bent behind her back. Looking at us, Leslie said, “I heard all the noise and, for a moment, I thought you were doing something else.”

Releasing Grace’s arm, with a grin, I said, “Oh we were doing that earlier; I’m surprised you didn’t hear us.”

The angry look on Leslie’s face told me that my joke was in poor taste. Before she could do anything, Grace stepped between us and said, “Babe relax, she was just kidding.” Pausing, Grace said, “I was just teaching her some self-defense.”

Calming down, Leslie looked at me and said, “That reminds me, I’ll buy you a thing of pepper spray for your purse.”

“Thanks.” Feeling apologetic, I said, “Sorry about that joke; I don’t know why I thought it would be funny.”

“That’s not the kind of joke you tell a pregnant woman, Amelia.”

Grace and Leslie left a short time later; after promising they’d be here tomorrow with the others to see me off. After saying goodbye to them, I closed the door and smiled – I’d be starting my new life tomorrow.
1111111113111111111111111.title: Back at the Hotel

11111111131111111111111111.content:
I woke up this morning, as I’d done every morning for the last few days, with a smile on my face. Today was the big day – the day I’d been working towards ever since I walked into New Horizons. I was leaving for Los Angeles and my new life as 26-year-old Amelia Webber.

I will admit to a tinge of remorse about leaving; after all, I’d spent my entire life in this area. But, as I sat up in bed, I knew it was for the best. Besides it wasn’t like I’d never see Kelsey and my mom again, I’d come back to visit once I felt the time was right.

Climbing out of bed, I went into the bathroom to shower; I was in the process of getting undressed when there was a knock at the door. Walking back into the room, I looked at the clock and saw that it was only 7:45. After putting on the bathrobe, I walked to the door – the whole time wondering who could be visiting at this hour.

Looking through the peephole, I saw a bellboy standing outside holding what appeared to be a garment bag. Opening the door, I said, “Can I help you?”

Handing me the garment bag, the bellboy said, “This was left for you at the front desk ma’am.”

“Thank you.” Gently placing the bag on the back of a nearby chair, I said, “Let me get some money for a tip, I’ll be right back.”

I went over to the desk where I’d left my purse the night before. I searched through it but had a hard time finding any cash. As I replayed the events of last night to figure out where it might have gone, I caught a glimpse of the bellboy staring at me in the mirror. I was ready to ignore the lewd looks he was giving me, until he said, “If you’re having trouble finding money, I’m willing to accept other arrangements.”

Feeling disgusted, I couldn’t help but shudder at that comment. God, men can be such pigs. I couldn’t help but chuckle slightly at that thought; I had been a man only a few days earlier. With that being said, I’d never talk to women like that. Placing the $15 back in my purse, I turned and around said, “You just talked yourself right out of a tip; next time, don’t talk to a woman like that.” Standing in the doorway, I said, “Now leave before I complain to your manager.”

The bellboy, visibly annoyed, turned and walked away. Even as he walked down the hall, I heard him grumble what sounded like “Dumb bitch.” Deciding not to make good on my threat, I closed the door and turned my attention to the garment bag. Opening it up, I saw that it contact a lovely, and recently pressed, tan skirt suit; along with a matching pair of heels at the bottom. I noticed a note inside the bag; which read:

You’re a mature woman now; might as well dress the part.
-- Eliza

After hanging the outfit up, I returned to the bathroom to get ready.
11111111131111111111111111.title: The Next Morning

111111111311111111111111111.content:
I was standing in front of the bathroom mirror, an hour later, finishing up my hair and make-up; having already gotten dressed and packed everything else. I couldn’t help but look at my reflection and try to picture what I used to look like only a few days earlier.

I was in the process of finishing up some mascara when there was a knock at the door. For a fleeting moment, I thought it was that creepy bellboy again until I heard Eliza’s voice. “Amelia, are you awake?”

Walking through the room to the door, I saw Eliza standing in the hall with Miranda, Leslie, and Grace. With a smile, I opened the door and said, “Hey guys, come on in.”

As everyone walked by, I noticed Leslie eyeing me as she walked by. “That suit looks amazing on you, Amelia.”

“Thanks.” Closing the door, I said, “I know I was made to not find this awkward or uncomfortable, but part of me still feels weird about wearing women’s clothing.”

“You did want to dress like a professional.” Standing next to Grace, Leslie said, “Trust me, give it a few more days and all that awkwardness will disappear.”

After a few minutes of idle conversation, we all sat down in the main room. Looking at me, Eliza said, “I’d imagine you’re wondering why we’re all here.”

“The thought had crossed my mind.” Crossing my legs, I said, “I just figured it was you guys being friendly; showing me how to be a woman.”

After casting a glance towards Eliza, Miranda turned to me and said, “We did want to show you the ropes, but we also wanted to be your friends.” Pausing, she said, “We do something similar for all our clients; tailor our relationship with them to fit what their new identity would be.”

“For example, had you decided to become an older guy; we would have become your wing girls.” Smiling, Leslie said, “Or surrogate children had you become an elderly woman.”

Looking at me, Eliza said, “That’s just a convoluted way of saying that we are your friends, or at least someone you can confide in.” grabbing her bag, Eliza pulled out a laptop and camera, “That reminds me, we’ve set up several social media accounts for you; Facebook, Twitter, etc. We just need to take a photo for your profile picture.”

After taking the obligatory profile photo, we all scrunched together for a group photo – five girlfriends hanging out. Once the photos were uploaded to the various accounts, I scrolled through Facebook and saw that I already had some friends, including those present. “How can I have friends already? I’ve never met any of these people.”

“Some of them are fake accounts controlled by a computer program we developed, but most are real people.” Looking at me, Leslie said, “Much like with your ‘parents’ we have employees who pretend to be friends when needed. In your situation, we’ve even paid people to say they were High School or College classmates, fellow cheerleaders, and I think one or two sorority sisters.”

“Wow, I’m impressed; you guys do think of everything.”

“That reminds me.” Grabbing an envelope from her bag, Eliza said, “Inside you’ll find your driver’s license, social security card, and a passport. I’ve also got you a first-class ticket to LA that leaves in about 4 hours.”

Taking the envelope, I said “First class, huh? I’ve always wondered what it would be like to sit in those seats.”

Miranda and Eliza looked at Leslie for a moment; she stared at them blankly for a moment until she suddenly said, “Oh right; your living arrangements are taken care of, you’re renting a room in a 25-year-old woman’s condo. Everything will be there when you arrive; clothes, makeup, and personal effects.” Pausing, she said, “I’ve also verified your interview for tomorrow morning at 9:30.”

I was starting to feel a little overwhelmed by everything; so much so that I started tearing up. After Grace gave me a tissue, I said,
“I can’t thank you, ladies, enough for everything you’ve done for me the last few days.” Wiping my eyes, I said, “When my mom and sister told me about this, I wasn’t sure it was a good idea. But now, I’ve never been surer about anything in my life.”

“This is the first day of the rest of your life, Amelia.” Hugging me, Leslie said, “You’re going to do great out in LA.”

Getting to her feet, Eliza said, “We should probably get going, the hotel has to clean the room for our next client.” Looking at me,
she said, “We’ve got a rental car downstairs for you; feel free to drive around a little before going to the airport.”
111111111311111111111111111.title: Continue

1111111113111111111111111111.content:
The ladies and I said more goodbyes in the parking lot before I got in my rental car; a 2017 Mustang. After waving goodbye to them, I drove out of the parking lot; surprised by how well I was handling the car. I’d never driven before today; before becoming Amelia, I’d been months away from getting my learner's permit. It wasn't till a moment later I realized they’d put the knowledge in my head – just like with my bra, my hair and make-up, and my ability to walk in heels.

I couldn’t resist the temptation so, once I came to a stoplight, I let my hair down and lowered the top. Once I started moving again, I relished the feeling of the wind in my hair. After driving along the beach for a few minutes, casually checking out some of the guys, I decided to take Eliza’s advice and drive around my former hometown. After all, it was going to be a while before I came back to visit.

The trip on the highway wasn’t long; before I knew it, I was driving through downtown passed all my old hangouts. At a stop sign, by the park, I noticed Kyle and David crossing the street in front of me. I had to force myself to play it cool, but that was difficult once they noticed me. I wasn’t sure what they were more impressed with – the attractive young woman in the car or the car itself.

I gave them both a polite wave before driving off; not long after, I found myself driving through my old neighborhood. It was the last day before school started tomorrow, so most of the kids were outside playing while they could. Some of them I knew quite well, having babysat for many of them. I couldn’t help but think that I’d have an easier time controlling Tommy Johnson now than I did before.

I soon found myself in front of my old house; I saw Mom’s car was gone, while Kelsey was out front practicing her cheer routines. I parked across the street and watched as she put herself through her paces – wrapping it all up with a perfect Double-9 jump.

Once she was done, she took a sip from a water bottle and saw me watching her from across the street. Without even thinking, I touched my lips with two fingers and turned them in her direction. It was our secret handshake, one that we’d done since we were kids. I suppose now it served to tell her that I was fine.

She reciprocated and then stared at me confused. Then the realization hit her and, even from across the street, I heard her say, “Kevin?”

She started jogging towards me; but I drove off before she got too close, I’d overstayed my welcome and wasn’t ready to reintroduce myself just yet. Besides; my flight left in 3 hours and I still needed to check-in for my flight. Maybe I'll get a drink at the bar or something.
1111111113111111111111111111.title: Driving by the House

11111111131111111111111111111.content:
After returning the car to the rental center, I took a shuttle to the terminal. I’d only flown three times in my life; who’d have thought my 4th would be as a woman. I gave the driver a nice tip as thanks for helping me when I stumbled off the shuttle. I’d heard horror stories about women twisting their ankles in heels; let’s just say I was grateful that I was able to walk it off.

With my suitcase in tow, I made my way inside to check-in. Taking into consideration the fact that school started tomorrow, I was surprised by the number of families around. Waiting in line, I realized that they were probably just flying home.

The woman behind the counter was a few years younger than me; chatty but not annoyingly so. She did compliment me on my outfit, however; which I thought was nice. The ladies at NHI had enrolled me in TSA Pre-Check, so I made it through security in less than 5 minutes. Once I was through security, I walked over to the departure board noticed that my flight was running about 30 minutes late.

I grumbled to myself in annoyance – I wanted to start my new life; not sit around the airport. Next to me, I heard a man say, “Dammit.” Choosing not to engage, figuring he was upset about a delay, I walked past him as he went to join a woman standing nearby with two young children.

After buying some a book at the store, not one of those mushy harlequin romance novels, I decided to stop by the bar for a drink. Taking to heart Leslie’s remark about me not holding my liquor, I figured it would be a good idea to improve my tolerance. That being said, I didn’t want to drink so much that I wouldn’t be on the plane; so I settled for a hard cider.

*******************************


I spent the better part of an hour at the bar, watching the people as they walked past on the way to their destinations. I’ll admit that it was kind of a turn-on: knowing that they saw me as an attractive young woman and not the teenage boy I used to be. I knew most of the people at the bar, including some of the women, wouldn’t be so interested in me had they known the truth.

I was finishing up my second hard cider when I heard footsteps behind me; followed by an intoxicated, yet familiar voice saying, “H-Hello be-beautiful.”

Great. Putting my drink down, I turned and found the man I’d seen at the departure board standing in front of me; not even attempting to hide the fact that he was looking at my chest.
11111111131111111111111111111.title: At the Airport

111111111311111111111111111111.content:
I don’t know what disturbed me more about this situation; the fact that this man was old enough to be my father, or that he was married. I was also aware of the fact that I’d had three encounters with creepy men in the last 12 hours. I turned towards the bartender, a middle-aged man, who gave me an apologetic look.

Putting my drink down, I decided to get the man to leave as quickly as possible. I wasn’t about to let some married man flirt with me. Turning to the man, I said, “What can I do for you, sir?”

The man inched closer to me; even putting a hand on my thigh as he slurred his speech. “Whada ya say we goes somewhere...somewhere private?”

This must’ve been my punishment for my actions at the pool yesterday; I was experiencing what I put that poor cabana boy through. I somewhat aggressively removed the man’s hand from my waist, said hand having moved further down my leg as the man talked. While the bartender went to the other end of the bar, I assumed to call the cops, I looked at him and said, “I’m sorry, but that’s not going to happen; since you’re old enough to be my father.” Sighing, repulsed, I said, “On top of all that, you’re drunk and you’re married.”

Unfortunately, that wasn’t enough for the man to get the hint, as he responded. “We can just have a quickie. I know a quiet spot...”

I suddenly heard the hurried sound of approaching footsteps, followed by an angry woman’s voice saying, “Harold! Get away from that woman!”

I looked up and breathed a sigh of relief as I saw the man’s wife walking into the bar. Seeing the look on her face, I assumed she was going to be angry with me as well. The bartender had the same assumption because he came out from behind the bar and said, “Ma’am, I’ve already called airport police; your husband has been acting very inappropriately towards this woman.”

The woman glared at her husband for a moment before calming down, ever so slightly, and turning to me. “I’m sorry, miss; this isn’t the first time he’s done something like this.” Turning back to her husband, she said, “Just for this, Harold; my mother will be staying with us – for four months.”

It took another twenty minutes for everything to be cleared up; the man was arrested for public intoxication and removed from his flight, while the wife decided that she and the kids would continue to Boston. After I gave my statement to the police, and the woman apologized again, the bartender came up to me and said, “Would you like something from the bar, ma’am? It’ll be on the house of course.”

“That’s okay.” Finishing off the last of my drink, I left a $10 bill on the bar. “I think I’m just going to sit at the gate and read my book.”

“I hope you have a pleasant flight, ma’am; and I’m sorry about what happened.”

As I walked through the terminal, I heard my cell phone ringing in my purse. Digging it out, I saw that it was Miranda calling.
Answering the call, I said, “Hey Miranda, what’s up?”

“Not much; had a few new clients come in this morning.” Pausing, Miranda said, “I was just calling to make sure you got to the airport okay.”

As I continued walking, I recounted everything that happened since I left. When I got to the part about Kelsey, I said, “In hindsight, I probably shouldn’t have let her see me, but I couldn’t leave without seeing her one last time.”

“That’s understandable; after all, she was your twin sister for 15 years.” Sighing, Miranda said, “Might I suggest you give yourself a few days to adjust to LA before contacting them.”

“I was going to do that anyway, but that’s good advice.” Taking a breath, I said, “I just hope I’ve had my last encounter with creepy men for a while. First, that guy at the bar last night and then the bellboy this morning implying I could sleep with him in place of a tip.”

“You’re an attractive woman, Amelia; I’m sorry to say, but creepy guys are kind of par for the course.”

“I can handle creepy guys that are my age, but I could do without older men hitting on me.” Taking a seat at the gate, I said, “I was at the airport bar, having a relaxing drink when this man came up who was old enough to be my father. He was drunk but the worst part was that he was married.”

“Oh wow, that’s just wrong.”

“Tell me about it.” Sighing, I said, “Why are men such pigs, Miranda?”

“Can’t help you there, girlfriend; I was born female, so I have no understanding about how the male mind works.”

“Say what you will about Kevin’s father; the man may have run off on his family, but he never hit on younger girls.” Leaning back, I said, “I’ll talk to you girls when I land in LA.”

“Sounds like a plan.” Chuckling, Miranda said, “Good luck out there, Amelia.”
111111111311111111111111111111.title: Dealing with a Drunk

1111111113111111111111111111111.content:
The 5 ½ hour flight to LA was largely uneventful; except for some turbulence as we flew through a storm over Colorado. Towards the end of the flight, I was awakened by a crying baby a few seats behind me. Guess I can’t get away from that even in First Class. As I settled back in my seat, I realized something – instead of being annoyed by the crying, I found myself feeling sympathy for the baby. I even had a different reaction to witnessing the mother breastfeeding the baby in the galley; instead of Kevin’s more prurient reaction to seeing a woman's bare breast, I found myself imagining myself taking care of my own child someday.

Once we landed, I decided to use the bathroom before heading to baggage claim. As I left the bathroom I bumped into a celebrity crush of Kevin’s. I mean that literally, I bumped into her as I left the bathroom. Looking at her, temporarily thrown off by the sight of her, I said, “Sorry about that.”

Carly Hawthorne played the younger lead actor in a show Kelsey and I used to watch; about a brother/sister crime-fighting team. I’d always wanted to meet her in person; but now that I did, I wish I hadn’t. Far from the sweet, and gentle character that she played on TV – in real life she was a bit of a jerk. “Watch where you’re going, bitch.”

Taken aback, I said, “Excuse me?”

“I said, watch where you're going!” looking at me, daggers in her eyes, she said, “What are you; deaf and stupid?"

I was silent as she went on her way; once she was gone I set about gathering my things off the floor. I was about to grab my passport when I saw someone else grab for it. “Excuse me, ma’am; let me get that for you.”

Standing up, I found myself face to face with Jake Tucker – the other lead character, and Kelsey’s celebrity crush. As Kevin I could never figure out why Kelsey liked him so much, but now I could see why. It turns out that the cameras don’t do him any justice. He was quite handsome. Blushing a little, I grabbed my passport and said, “Thank you.”

“No problem.” With a smile and a wave, he was off; leaving me staring as he walked off.

******************************


One of the pieces of paper I’d been given contained directions on where to find my car; directions which I followed to another 2017 Mustang convertible on the 3rd level of the parking garage. After feeding the address of my new home into the GPS, I put the top down and left the airport just as the sun started to rise.

I arrived at the address about 45 minutes later; a modest 2 story house in a quiet neighborhood about 25 minutes from downtown. After ringing the doorbell, I was greeted by a woman my age wearing lounge pants and a t-shirt. Judging from her appearance I figured I had woken her up. “Hi, I’m Amelia Webber.” Offering my hand, I said, “Are you Caitlin Saunders?"

“What, were you expecting Oprah?” with a gruff tone, she said, “Come on in, I’ll show you to your room. Your stuff got here yesterday afternoon.”

As Caitlin led me upstairs, I said, “This is a great house you’ve got here, I’m sure I’ll love living here.” Smiling, I said, “I’m sure we’ll be...”

Interrupting me, Caitlin said, “Your rent for this month’s been taken care of; it’s due on the 1st of the month. Bounce one check, and your shits on the front lawn.” Looking at me, she said, “Clean up after yourself, I’m not going to be your maid. If you see something in the fridge with my name on it, that means, if you want any, you've got to go out and buy it yourself."

As I followed her down the hall, I started to worry that I’d bitten off more than I chewed. Caitlin didn’t seem to be a very cheerful person. As we arrived outside a closed door, I said, “It seems like we’ve gotten off on the wrong foot.” Smiling, I said, “I’d like for us to be friends.”

Caitlin grumbled as she opened the door; walking back down the hall to another room. I jumped a bit as she slammed the door shut. Looking inside the room, I saw almost a dozen boxes scattered around a brand new mattress. I guess Caitlin wasn’t interested in unpacking for me either. Good thing they labeled all the boxes, I thought as I opened up the first box.. What a difference L.A. is from New Jersey.
1111111113111111111111111111111.title: Los Angeles

11111111131111111111111111111111.content:
It was just before 8 AM, an hour after I arrived at the house. I had just finished putting away three boxes of clothes when I decided to tackle my toiletries. One of the perks that I was grateful for was that my room came with its own ensuite bathroom; something that Caitlin’s room also had.

I was in the process of putting away my feminine hygiene products, all the while dreading my first menstrual cycle, when I heard footsteps in the hall. Walking back into my room, I poked my head out the door and saw Caitlin walking, I saw Caitlin coming from her room – dressed in a similar outfit to mine. Seeing me looking at her, she said, “I’m heading into work; I left a set of keys in the kitchen if you feel like leaving the house.”

Despite the less than stellar start we had earlier, I was desperate to have a positive relationship with this woman. After all, I gave up everything to start a new life for myself; I wasn’t going to let someone with a confrontational attitude ruin that for me. Stepping out of the bathroom, I said, “If you don’t mind my asking, Caitlin, what do you do for a living?”

“I work in casting over at Paramount; it’s nothing too glamorous but it sometimes gets me in the room with some big-name celebrities.” With a hint of a smile, Caitlin said, “Just last week I spent the day with Chris Pratt while we auditioned young girls to play his daughter in an upcoming movie.”

The thought of being in a room all day with Chris Pratt had an unexpected reaction; if my erect nipples were any indication, I was getting turned on. “I can’t imagine how hard it must be not to flirt with all the actors you meet.”

“I’d be lying if I said it never crossed my mind; after all, I am a woman.” Pausing, Caitlin said, “But then I find myself struggling to imagine how I’d be able to pay my bills if I lost my job.”

I wanted to continue the conversation with Caitlin in an attempt to get to know her better; but then I realized that she was trying to leave for work. Looking at her, I said, “I guess I’ll see you after work then.” With a smile, I said. “I’m probably going to do a little more unpacking and then head into the city to get the lay of the land.”

Caitlin didn’t say anything in response, only smiling at me as she walked down the stairs. Once she was out the door, I leaned against the wall and sighed. I couldn’t shake the feeling that she didn’t like me very much. I was about to go back into the bathroom when I heard my cell phone ringing down the hall. Going to my room, I saw that Leslie was calling me. Answering it, I said, “Hey Leslie.”

I must’ve sounded a tad depressed over the phone, because Leslie immediately said, “Uh oh, what’s wrong? You don’t like someone who just started a new life.”

Sitting down on my bed, I spent the next 15 minutes talking about everything that’s happened to me since I left the hotel; culminating in my less than positive first meeting with Caitlin. “I don’t know what I’m supposed to do, Leslie; 7 hours into my new life and I’ve already been hit on by someone old enough to be my father, called a dumb bitch by an actress I used to be attracted to and, on top of that, I’m pretty sure my roommate doesn’t like me.”

“You’ve got to take things slowly, Amelia; you’re expecting too much from your first day on your own.” Sighing, Leslie said, “My first day on my own wasn’t all that good either; let’s just say I quickly learned being a young lesbian in the Deep South wasn’t going to cut it.”

“What do you suggest I do then?”

“Honey, you’re in Los Angeles; chances are you’ll bump into a random celebrity on the street.” Pausing, Leslie said, “Go out and explore a little; get acquainted with your new home.”

“I suppose I could do that; after all, I’ve always wanted to come out here on vacation.” Sitting on the bed, I said, “Not that I don’t mind the call; but I doubt you called just to say hi.”

“Damn pregnancy brain, I completely spaced on that.” Chuckling, Leslie said, “Your, uh, former family placed an obituary in the local paper; we didn’t see it until after you’d already left.”

I knew that was coming but I hadn’t thought about how I’d react to the news. “Oh wow; they didn’t wait long.”

“I’ll email it to you, but they’re saying that Kevin died suddenly in his sleep.”

Standing up, walking around a little bit, I said, “I know they did all this last minute and everything, but I can’t help but think they could’ve come up with something a little more interesting.”

“Might I suggest discussing that with them once you make contact?” pausing, Leslie said, “I’ll talk to you later, honey; go enjoy the sights.”

After hanging up the phone, I decided to take Leslie up on her suggestion. So I changed out of the skirt suit and into a pair of shorts and a t-shirt. Grabbing everything I’d need for a day on the town, I locked up the house and drove towards downtown.
11111111131111111111111111111111.title: Settling In

111111111311111111111111111111111.content:
It was just after Noon and I was casually strolling along the Venice Beach Boardwalk. I’d visited a few of the major tourist spots; like the Walk of Fame and the Chinese Theater. I was starting to get a little hungry so I crossed the street to a small café.

After giving my order, a small chicken salad with an iced tea, I couldn’t help but do some people watching. I was well aware of the fact that I was now a heterosexual woman, but there were still times when I was surprised to find myself checking out some random guy as he walked by.

My food came 10 minutes later; I had just taken a sip of my iced tea when I heard a voice next to me say, “Well hello again.”

Looking up I saw the guy from the airport; before I could stop myself, I dropped my tea on the ground. Already mortified beyond belief, I became more so when I saw that some of my drink had gotten on his shoes. Grabbing my napkin, I reached down and started wiping it off while a server came to clean up my mess. “Oh my God, I’m so sorry.”

“It’s okay, don’t worry about it.” Gently grabbing my hand, the man said, “These are just a cheap pair of sneakers; who cares if they get dirty.”

As the man took a seat across from me, I sat back down and said, “I’m usually not that clumsy.”

“Don’t worry; stuff like this happens all the time.” Chuckling, the man said, “To be honest, I’d rather have iced tea on my shoes than have someone’s coffee on my shirt.”

A server brought me a new iced tea; as I continued eating my lunch while we talked. After hearing about Leslie’s experience on her first date, I was glad the salad gave me something to do while he spoke. The more I looked at him, the more I realized why other girls thought he was so attractive. “I’ve been watching your show since High School; I’d be lying if I said I didn’t have a little crush on you back then.” With a smile, I wiped some dressing on my face and said, “If someone told me that I’d be sitting at a café chatting with Malcolm Tucker, I would have thought them insane.”

Taking a sip from his soda, Malcolm smiled and said, “So you’re a fan of the show?”

I felt bad about lying to the guy; even if it was only about some minor details. Looking at him, I said, “Yeah, I’ve never missed an episode.” Pausing, I said, “It amazes me how the writers have been able to keep it so fresh after 10 seasons.”

“There have been some instances where storylines were reused; but yeah, I guess they have done a decent job.” Sighing, Malcolm said, “It’s still a lot of fun working on the show; but to be honest, I’m getting tired. My contract came up for renegotiation last month; I’ve kind of been stalling about whether or not to renew it.”

The idea of the show coming to an end didn’t sit well with me, but I couldn’t blame the guy for getting fatigued. Looking at Malcolm, I said, “If you don’t mind me asking, what would you like to do after the show ends?”

“I just finished filming a movie last month; it comes out around Thanksgiving.” Sighing, Malcolm said, “If it’s successful, I’d like to transition to the big screen.”

Thinking back to what Malcolm had said about his enjoyment from working on the show, I recalled my encounter with his costar at the airport. “I have to admit; after bumping into your costar at the airport, it’s hard to believe working with her could be fun.”

“Did Elena leave you with a bad first impression?” looking at me, Malcolm said, “I’m sorry about that, but she’s a really sweet person once you get to know her.”

I couldn’t help but chuckle at that idea. “Sorry, but what chance does a small-town girl from New Jersey have to get to know a TV star.”

“We’ve been talking for almost an hour; so I’d say the chances are really good.” Pausing, Malcolm said, “It just dawned on me that you know who I am, but I don’t know who you are.”

“Let’s remedy that, shall we?” extending my hand, I said, “My name’s Amelia Webber.”

Shaking my hand, Malcolm said, “It’s nice to meet you, Amelia.” Looking past me, he said, “What do you know, it looks like you’ll get a chance to meet Elena after all.”

Turning around, I saw Elena Johnson walking towards us; her demeanor much different from when I’d encountered her at the airport.
111111111311111111111111111111111.title: Seeing the Sights

1111111113111111111111111111111111.content:
Walking up to the table, Elena said, “How are you doing, Mal? Did you make a new - Oh, my God!"

I watched as all color drained from Elena’s face; which led to a smirk, and a wink, from Malcolm. “I take it then that you remember Amelia?”

“I’m sorry about this morning.” Taking a seat next to me, Elena placed a hand on my shoulder and said, “I’m not the biggest fan of flying; so I can get rather testy, and my PMDD doesn’t help at all.”

I’d never heard of that before now, it wasn’t something Kelsey experienced to my knowledge. “PMDD?”

“Yeah, it stands for premenstrual dysphoric disorder; imagine the worst period you’ve ever had, and multiply that by 50 for me.” Sighing, Elena said, “I was a walking time bomb this morning; unfortunately you found yourself in my crosshairs. I’m sorry about that, miss... I'm sorry what did you say your name was?"

While silently hoping I never experienced PMDD, I couldn’t stop thinking about how I’d only been in LA for a few hours and I was already on a first-name basis with two celebrities. “Amelia Webber.”

“My name’s Elena Johnson, but I suspect you already know that.” Looking at me, she said, “Thanks for not going to TMZ after our first meeting, Amelia.”

“Don’t worry, that was the last thing on my mind this morning.” Sighing, I said, “I just moved out here from New Jersey, so I was more focused on getting settled.”

His interest piqued, Malcolm said, “What brings you out here from Jersey?”

“Work; I’m hoping to get into the entertainment industry.” Seeing a flash of concern across Elena’s face, I turned to her and said, “Don’t worry; I’m going for something behind the scenes, I’ve got an interview at a talent agency tomorrow morning.”
While Elena breathed a sigh of relief, Malcolm said, “Really? What agency?”

At that moment I forgot the name of the agency; try as I might, I couldn’t remember it. “You know what, I-I’ve completely blanked on the name.”

“Not a problem, I hope you nail the interview.” Smiling, Elena said, “What were you guys talking about when I showed up?”

“Nothing major, just my plans for once the show’s over.”

“Look at you, Mr. Big Shot with your big screen movie.” Groaning, Elena said, “All I’ve got is a role in some Christmas movie on Hallmark Channel.”

“Hey it’s a start, right?” pausing, I said, “What's it about?”

“It’s a Christmas movie on the Hallmark Channel, so the same thing as every other movie they’ve done.” Sighing, Elena said, “Some big-shot executive, with an 8-figure salary, returns home and throws it all away to be with some boy she knew in High School. I play the part of the guy’s kid sister; who fixes them up."

“Hey if Kevin Bacon and Holly Hunter can get their start being killed in slasher movies, you can make a Hallmark Christmas movie."

With a smile, Elena said, “You sound just like my agent."

“I’m not there yet, but that’s the dream.”

As the three of us continued talking, I began to notice something: when I was talking, Malcolm was focused on my lips. When he, or Elena, spoke he would look at me – not just my boobs and butt, the way so many men had, but all{/i) of me.

We kept talking until my salad and iced tea were gone, and then we went our separate ways.
1111111113111111111111111111111111.title: Two Celebrities & A Girl From Jersey

11111111131111111111111111111111111.content:
It was just after 4:00 when I decided it was time to head back home; having just done a tour of the Queen Mary museum in Long Beach. As I drove onto the freeway, I found myself remembering that LA was notorious for rush hour traffic; and hoped I didn’t have an issue.

Thankfully I didn’t experience much in the way of traffic; getting back to the house just before 5:00 to find that Caitlin’s car was in the driveway. As I got out of the car, I remembered my desire to have a friendship with Caitlin. After locking my car, I walked up to the front door and let myself inside.

The moment I did, I heard Caitlin’s voice coming from down the hall; it sounded like she was talking to someone. Going down the hall, I found Caitlin spread out in the breakfast nook having a conversation with someone over the phone. “She seems like a nice enough girl, Mom; but after what happened with Carly, I want to exercise some caution.” Looking up from the phone, Caitlin saw me standing in the doorway. Throwing me a wave, she returned to the phone call, “No Mom, I haven’t spoken with Carly or Brandon since they moved out; and frankly I don’t know if want to.”

Feeling thirsty, I walked over to the fridge and opened it; grabbing a can of diet coke from the door. As I opened it, I heard Caitlin say, “I’ll talk to you later, Mom; I’ve got to start making dinner.”

After she hung up the phone, I looked at her and said, “I didn’t mean to eavesdrop on your conversation.”

“It’s alright.” Getting up, Caitlin placed the phone back on the charger. “I’m making chicken tetrazzini for dinner, you want some?”

“Sure, that sounds nice.” As Caitlin walked by me, I said, “About this morning; I want us to be friends, but I couldn’t help but feel we got off on the wrong foot.”

“Let’s not rush into things, Amelia; I’ve been burned because of that before.” Looking at me, Caitlin said, “You seem like a nice girl, but I think we should get to know each other a little better.”

“Does that cautious attitude have anything to do with Carly or Brandon?”

Caitlin looked me; a look of anger briefly flashing across her face. “Carly was my college roommate, and Brandon was my boyfriend.” Sighing, Caitlin said, “The three of us lived here, together, for three years; until I found out that they’d been sleeping with each other behind my back.”

“Oh; I guess I can understand you're being cautious around me then.” Looking at Caitlin, I said, “I’m not the kind of girl to sleep with someone’s boyfriend, so you don’t have to worry about that.”

********************************


The dinner took about an hour to make, even with some help from me. She was still somewhat reserved, but Caitlin had opened up a little bit. The two of us were sitting at the table, eating and talking. “You know a decent amount about me, Amelia; but I don’t know anything about you.” Looking at me, taking a bite, Caitlin said, “Why don’t you tell me about yourself?”

“There’s not much to tell, really; I’m from New Jersey and I’m the first in my family to go to college.” Sighing, I said, “I wasn’t happy with the life I had back east, so I went to New Horizons and they helped me get my life back on track.”

“I’ve only heard a little bit about what they do, something about making changes to a person’s life or something like that.” Chuckling, Caitlin said, “I honestly never gave them much thought until one of their reps came by, offering me $1500 a month to let you live here.”

“So if they’re giving you $1500 a month, shouldn’t that more than cover my rent?”

“Wow, you don’t beat around the bush; do you.” Putting her fork down, Caitlin said, “I’ll tell you what; let’s see how things go for the next few weeks. If we don’t kill each other, I’ll put the $1500 towards your monthly rent; all you’ll have to do is chip in some money for utilities and groceries. How’s that sound?”

With a smile on my face, I nodded and said. “I think I can live with that.”

“Since you’ve asked me some personal questions, I hope you don’t mind if I do the same.” Looking at me, Caitlin said, “What exactly did New Horizons do to help you get your life back on track? Pay off your debt? Take care of some legal troubles?”

I was hesitant to come clean about this so early, but I figured there was no harm in it. “No, it wasn’t anything like that.” Taking a deep breath, I said, “They changed me from a 14-year-old boy to the 26-year-old woman you see before you.”
11111111131111111111111111111111111.title: Getting to Know Caitlin

111111111311111111111111111111111111.content:
To say that Caitlin was stunned would have been an understatement; she was silent for a good five minutes after I told her the truth, doing nothing but stare at me. I started to feel weirded out, worried that she was going to have a less than positive reaction. When she finally spoke again, she said, “You’re kidding, right?” looking at me, she said, “There’s no possible way you could’ve been a 14-year-old boy.”

“Caitlin, I promise I’m telling the truth.” Looking at her, I said, “I was extremely unhappy in my former life, bordering on the suicidal, so my former family brought me to New Horizons. After answering some questions, and being injected with some nanites, I became the woman you see before you.”

I then went on to explain the process I went through to become Amelia; from the interview to the psychological evaluation and life design to the procedure itself. By the time I was finished, Caitlin was pacing around the kitchen floor. “Let’s say I believe you, which I don’t by the way; why would a 14-year-old boy decide to give up 12 years of his life and become a woman?”

“I’ll be honest, I didn’t give that much thought; I just figured I’d try for something completely different from my former life.” With a slight grin, I said, “What could be more different than becoming a 26-year-old woman.”

“Forgive me if this is at all inappropriate, but I just have to ask.” Walking over to me, Caitlin knelt in front of me and said, “Are you... how should I put this, 100% female?”

“I’m as much a woman as you are; right down to my ovaries and my uterus.” With a pause, I said, “As a matter of fact, I’m due for my first period in a few days.”

After that, Caitlin asked me a few more questions before I went upstairs to retrieve the photos I’d gotten from Kelsey. As she looked at them, Caitlin said, “I chickened out on getting a tattoo, but here you went through such a dramatic transformation.” Putting the photos down, she said, “That must’ve been hard to leave your family.”

“It was, but we all knew where I could’ve ended up had I not gone through with this.” Gathering up the photos, I said, “That’s not to say I’ll never see them again; I’ll wait a few months before I fly back to see them.”

When Caitlin looked at me now, I saw no hint of the girl I’d first met this morning. Taking a seat next to me, Caitlin said, “I know we just met, but it means a lot that you trusted me with your story.”

“I’m glad you took it all in stride; I was worried that you’d react negatively.” Breathing a sigh of relief, I said, “It’s nice to have someone, out here, who I can talk to.”

“This is California, girl; and it’s the 21st century.” Looking at me, a smile on her face, Caitlin said, “Our state motto could be changed to ‘Cool, yo' and no one would bat an eye.”

“It still means a lot that you’re so understanding about this.”

“There is one thing I’m curious about; you’ve only been a woman for a few days, right?”

I wasn’t sure where Caitlin was going with this so, looking perplexed, I said, “Yeah, it’ll be 5 days tomorrow. Why?”

“How much do you know about being a woman?” looking at me, she said, “I can’t imagine you knew very much going in.”

“During the procedure, they gave me all the basic knowledge I’d need; hair and makeup, how to handle a bra and walking in heels.” Sighing, I said, “I’ve got a lot to learn about flirting; and, as one my girlfriends would say, I can’t hold my alcohol yet.”

“I’m not sure I can help you with the flirting; especially considering what happened with my last boyfriend.” Getting up, Caitlin retrieved a bottle of wine and some glasses. Walking back over to me, she said, “But I think I can help you with the second; what do you say to some inexpensive wine and a chick flick?”

With a grin and a chuckle, I said, “That’s the best idea I’ve heard all day.”
111111111311111111111111111111111111.title: Caitlin's Disbelief

1111111113111111111111111111111111111.content:
Caitlin and I stayed up watching movies until shortly after 10:00. Okay, so maybe the movies were playing in the background while we drank wine and talked. We both spoke about our childhoods and families; I wouldn’t say we were friends yet, but I figured we were well on our way.

When I woke up the next morning to my alarm clock, I found that I didn’t feel as hung-over as I had previously. After making a mental note to stick with wine instead of hard liquor, I climbed out of bed and made my way to the bathroom.

I was about to step into the shower when I heard a commotion outside; going over to the window, I noticed a handful of older children getting onto a waiting school bus. I then remembered that today would’ve been Kevin’s first day back at school; I couldn’t help but wonder how things would go for Kelsey and my friends now that word of my ‘death’ had gotten out.

I then reminded myself that that was no longer my concern; Kevin’s life was behind me now, I was living Amelia’s life. As I climbed into the shower, my thoughts turned to my interview this morning and I’ll admit that I was a tad nervous.

***********************


I walked into the kitchen about 30 minutes later; looking professional in my new skirt suit and heels. Caitlin was standing over by the coffee maker; looking up at me, she smiled and said, “Wow, you weren’t kidding about them giving you everything you’d need to be a woman.” With a chuckle, she said, “I’ve been a woman my entire life; I’ve never gotten my hair or makeup to look remotely as good as yours.”

“I guess they wanted to give me every advantage they could.” Walking over to the counter, I said, “Do you mind if I borrow one of our travel mugs for the day?”

“Go right ahead; I’ve got plenty of them.” Watching as I filled one of the mugs with coffee, Caitlin said, “How are you feeling about the interview?”

“I’m feeling hopeful, and a little nervous.” Putting the lid on the mug, I said, “I’ve never been to an interview before, so I have no idea what I’m walking into.”

“I’ll tell you what I tell people when they’re auditioning; just take it one step at a time.” Placing a hand on my shoulder, Caitlin said, “You’ve got this, Amelia.”

“Thanks.” Noticing the time, I said, “I should probably get going; I don’t want to get stuck in traffic.”

As I started walking out of the room, Caitlin called out, “Why don’t you stop by the studio afterward; we can get an early lunch and I’ll show you around.”

The thought of getting a behind the scenes tour of a major studio was appealing. Turning around in the doorway, I said, “I’d like that.”

“Great, I’ll give your name to security so they’ll let you in.” with a smile, Caitlin said, “Good luck.”
1111111113111111111111111111111111111.title: The Next Morning

11111111131111111111111111111111111111.content:
The talent agency took up three floors of a 10 story office building downtown; I was sitting in a well-lit waiting room with several other people, including a man and two other women. The longer I sat there, the more anxious I started to get – I began to wonder if the others in the room could tell I wasn’t what I seemed. I then reminded myself that that was absurd; after all, I was both physically and mentally a woman.

My interview was the second to last one; both the man and one of the women were called in before me. I started to get nervous again, this time because of the interview itself. It didn’t help that the man came out of the room drenched in sweat. He’s not getting the job. To help with my anxiety, I decided to strike up a conversation with the other woman.

Getting up, I walked over and sat down next to her, “I don’t know about you, but I’m pretty nervous about all of this.”

The woman, a slightly younger woman of Asian descent, turned to face me. I was taken aback when I saw the look of contempt on her face. “I’m not nervous at all; one call from my father and I can get any job I want in this town.”

That was all I needed to hear to know that this woman was incredibly spoiled; she was probably only interviewing for the job because her ‘daddy’ was making her. I didn’t want to be rude, but I also didn’t want to talk with her. Getting up, with a fake smile,
I said, “Well good luck.”

Thankfully I didn’t have long to wait; barely a minute after I got back to my seat, the second candidate came walking down the hall along with another young woman. After thanking the candidate for coming, the woman looked into the room. “Amelia Webber?”

Here goes nothing. Getting to my feet, I said, “That’s me, I’m Amelia Webber.”

“Follow me, please.”

************************************


I took it as a good sign that my interview lasted longer than the first two combined; although I was still incredibly nervous the entire time. The woman I was interviewing with, Meredith Geller, was slightly older than my…rather Kevin’s mom had been. The position I was interviewing for was to be her assistant.

The whole time I was answering questions, I feared that she would realize my degrees and job experience were faked. To be fair, the job experience was faked but the degrees were real.

I had just finished answering one of those ‘where do you see yourself in 5 years’ questions; saying that I hoped to become a talent agent as well, maybe eventually open an agency of my own someday. For some reason or another, Meredith liked my answer. “Well, I’ve got all the information I need.” Getting to her feet, Meredith reached out her hand and said, “You’ve got the job, Ms. Webber.”

To say that I was relieved would be an understatement; all my anxiety and nervousness had been for naught. After realizing that I’d gone almost a minute without responding, I quickly grabbed Meredith’s hand and said, “Thank you so much, ma’am; you won’t be disappointed.”

The two of us walked out of the room; where she introduced me to the woman I’d be replacing. By pure coincidence, the spoiled woman from before was walking out of the nearby bathroom when Meredith said, “Brianna; I’d like for you to meet your replacement, Amelia Webber.”

As Brianna got to her feet, I swear I saw the other woman giving me a death stare. She turned and walked out in a huff, while Brianna said, “It’s a pleasure to meet you, Amelia.”

“The pleasure’s all mine, Brianna.”

Looking at the two of us, Meredith said, “Brianna is leaving us for an administrative job at Pixar; she’s leaving some big shoes to fill, but I’m sure you’re up to the task Amelia.”

I stayed for a few more minutes; chatting with Brianna and learning that my training would start on Monday. I was grateful for that because it gave me four days to relax beforehand. After once again, thanking Meredith I gathered my things and left.

I knew she was probably busy, so I decide to simply text Leslie – I got the job! Getting into my car, I plugged in the address for Paramount and drove off for my lunch with Caitlin.
11111111131111111111111111111111111111.title: The Interview

111111111311111111111111111111111111111.content:
Thanks to some late-morning traffic, what should have been a 20-minute drive turned into an almost 40 minute one. I’d become mildly annoyed by the traffic by time I drove through the gate at Paramount. After giving my name to the guard, I was given directions to where I needed to go.

I parked my car in one of the visitor spots outside of Caitlin’s office and walked inside. After taking the elevator up to Caitlin’s floor, I walked up to the receptionist. Trying my best to look professional, I said, “My name’s Amelia Webber, I’m here to see Caitlin Saunders.”

“I’m afraid Ms. Saunders doesn’t take walk-ins, ma’am.” Looking at me, the receptionist said, “I can give you her number if you’d like to make an appointment for an audition.”

I was a little annoyed by the thought that I was someone walking in from the streets in the hopes of getting an audition. “Sorry, I think there’s been a mistake; I’m not here for an audition. I’m Caitlin’s roommate; we’re having lunch together.”

The receptionist went pale as a ghost, as if she’d made a horrible mistake, “I’m so sorry, ma’am; I’ll let her know you’re here.”

I took a seat in the waiting area while I waited for Caitlin to come out. The receptionist, probably trying to make up for her mistake, offered me water but I politely declined. I was only waiting a few minutes before Caitlin walked down the hall. Upon seeing me, a smile on her face, she came over and hugged me.

After exchanging pleasantries, she led me down the hall to her office. While we were walking, she turned to me and said, “How’d the interview go?”

With a smile on my face, I said, “I nailed it, I start training on Monday.”

“Girl I knew you were going to nail that interview.” Stepping in her office, which was a pretty decent size, Caitlin said, “Why don’t you have a seat; I just have to send out some emails and then we’ll go to lunch.”

As I took a seat, I said, “I’m not that hungry yet; I was wondering if we could take that tour first.”

Looking up from her computer, Caitlin said, “It’s totally up to you, we’ll do whatever you feel like.”
111111111311111111111111111111111111111.title: Paramount Studios

1111111113111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The more I thought about it, the more I realized that I was getting pretty hungry; after all, I was so nervous this morning that I hadn’t eaten breakfast. “On second thought I could go for some lunch, then perhaps we can do the tour after.”

“That works for me.” Grabbing her purse and phone, Caitlin said, “If we hurry, we might run into some of the actors at the commissary.”

The thought of seeing even more celebrities appealed to me, as I followed Caitlin down the hall to the elevator. As we waited for the elevator to arrive, I decided to pass the time by regaling Caitlin with the story of my encounter with that woman at the interview. “I’m sure you probably see people like this all the time; but while I was waiting for my turn to be interviewed, I decided to strike up a conversation with this other woman in the waiting room.” sighing, I said, “When I asked her if she was nervous, she told me that her father could get her any job she wanted with just a phone call.”

“Oh god, I hate people like that; they’re so spoiled.” The elevator arrived at that moment. As we walked inside, Caitlin said, “I remember, last year, auditioning this teenager for a spot on some reality TV that didn’t even make it to air. She was terrible but I had to give her an audition because her father was some big executive.”

“It amazes me that people think that’s how the world works; that they’ll get anything they want solely because of who they’re related to.”

“I know it’s not exactly the same, but you’re only out here because you went to New Horizons.” Looking at me, as the elevator started its descent, Caitlin said, “If you hadn’t become a woman and moved out here, who knows who could have gotten that job.”

As I stood there I realized that, in a way, Caitlin was correct. The big reason I got this new job was that I went to New Horizons. Then again, they just changed me and gave me the necessary education; I was the one that wowed Meredith at the interview. Looking at her, I said, “You don’t think I’m like that other woman, do you?”

The gravity of what she said must’ve dawned on Caitlin; as her eyes went wide and she looked at me. “Not exactly; sure you got that job with help from someone else, but you’re nothing like that other woman.” With a short pause, Caitlin said, “At least from what little I’ve seen, and heard about your former life, you’re the polar opposite of that woman.”

I couldn’t shake the feeling that Caitlin didn’t believe that; that she actually thought I was in the same boat as that other woman. But in an attempt to change the conversation, and keep the two of us from arguing in an elevator, I said, “So what’s the food like here?”

“It’s extremely overpriced, but it’s actually quite good.” Looking at me, Caitlin said, “I can guarantee it’s better than anything you’d get for lunch at school.”
1111111113111111111111111111111111111111.title: Heading to Lunch

1111111113111111111111111111111111111111.content:
As it turned out, Caitlin was right on both counts; the food was overpriced ($8 for a pre-made salad and a drink) but it was still better than anything I’d ever had at school. The two of us had a conversation between bites; mostly idle conversation but I did learn a little more about her.

“What made you want to get involved in casting?”

Taking a sip of her soda, Caitlin looked at me and said, “I was a bit of a theater geek in high school; I helped out with pretty much every aspect of production.” Taking a breath, Caitlin continued, “I wasn’t the best actress, but I was great behind the scenes; so once college started I decide to major in film production.”

“Did you ever regret not getting any formal acting training?”

“Nope, none at all; I’m perfectly happy with my career. I’m pretty sure I’m on the shortlist to replace my boss when he retires next year.” Sighing, Caitlin said, “Really the only regret I have is staying with my ex for 5 years.”

I thought back to the terrible luck my mom had dating after my dad left; a lot of her dates bailed the moment they learned she had two young kids. I couldn’t help but feel bad for Caitlin having put all that time and effort into a relationship, only for her ex to cheat on her. “He couldn’t have been that bad; after all, you were together for 5 years.”

“This coming from a former 14-year-old boy who, on her first day as a woman, thought it would be wise to strip in front of half a dozen children.”

I knew that little story would come back to bite me; I just figured it would take longer. Taking a deep breath, I said, “First off; I was drunk. Secondly; there were only two kids at the pool.”

It looked as if Caitlin was about to say something else; until she got all jumpy for a moment. “Don’t look now, but a very cute guy just walked into the room.”

Thinking that perhaps it was a co-worker of Caitlin’s that she liked, I turned around to look; only to discover that it was Malcolm. The sight of him walking through the buffet line caused me to blush. I don’t know what came over me, but I stood up and hollered, “Malcolm!”

Everyone in the room turned to face me; as Caitlin, looking mortified, grabbed me and pulled me back into my seat. “What are you doing!? He’s an actor, you can’t just...”

Caitlin stopped midsentence as Malcolm stopped in front of our table. With a smile on his face, Malcolm looked at me and said, “Hey Amelia, I didn’t expect to see you here.”

Caitlin’s expression quickly changed from embarrassed to shock; as she just stared at Malcolm and me. Once she got her voice back, her mouth agape, she said, “You’re on a first-name basis with Malcolm Tucker; star of Double Trouble.”

Taking a seat at our table, Malcolm said, “We met at the airport yesterday; she dropped her passport and I retrieved it for her.” With a grin, he said, “Then we met again at a café in Venice Beach, where she slipped a glass of iced tea on my shoes.”

Turning to Caitlin, I said, “After Elena showed up, the three of us spent almost an hour talking with each other.”
1111111113111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lunch & A Familiar Face

1111111113111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The three of us sat and talked for about 30 minutes, while Malcolm taking a break from filming some scenes for the show. I suppose I couldn’t blame her, but I couldn’t help but be a little annoyed by her acting like a fangirl. She wouldn’t stop asking Malcolm questions about the show, or other celebrities that he’d worked with.

Malcolm, to his credit, answered every question; but I couldn’t help but notice he was focusing his attention on me. I’d already told him everything the day before, so all that was left was just idle chit-chat.

Eventually, Malcolm’s break came to an end and he went back to the set; but not before taking a quick selfie with Caitlin and me. As Caitlin and I walked out of the commissary a few minutes later, she turned to me and said, “I can’t believe how dull my life was before you showed up.” Stopping in the parking lot, she said, “That’s the longest conversation I’ve had with an actor that wasn’t work-related.”

As we continued walking, I said, “Malcolm seems like a pretty down to earth kind of guy.”

“Plus he was totally flirting with you.”

Now it was my turn to stop; turning to Caitlin, I said, “You’re kidding, right? Malcolm was not flirting with me.”

“He was so flirting with you, Amelia; and, at least subconsciously, I think you were flirting with him as well.” Looking at me, she said, “Forget for a moment that you used to be a teenage boy; have you ever known a guy to spend 30 minutes talking with an attractive woman about the weather?”

The more I thought about it, the more I realized that Caitlin may have a point. With the looks that he'd been giving me yesterday, plus the fact 30 minutes of idle conversation over lunch, there was a distinct possibility that Malcolm was at least interested in me. “Even if we were flirting with each other, he’s way out of my league.” Sighing, as we crossed the road going towards a row of parked golf carts, I said, “He’s an actor and I’m a glorified secretary; I couldn’t get a guy like that in a million years.”

“The heart wants what the heart wants, Amelia.” Taking a seat in one of the carts, Caitlin said, “Mark my words, very soon Malcolm will be asking you on a date.”
1111111113111111111111111111111111111111.title: After Lunch

1111111113111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Caitlin and I drove around the studio for around 25 minutes; where I was shown the various soundstages and even got to tour the New York backlot. Eventually, Caitlin’s lunch ended and we returned to her office. As we stood outside, in the parking lot, I turned to her and said, “Thanks for all this, Caitlin; I had fun.”

“I had fun too; this isn’t something I regularly get to do.” looking at me, she said, “Before I head back inside, I need to know; can you cook?”

I was confused by the sudden change of topic, so I was silent for a moment. “What?”

“Can you cook? Because if you can tonight’s your turn.”

After the pleasant lunch I’d had with her, I was taken aback by Caitlin’s sudden change in attitude; similar, but not identical, to when we’d first met. “Yeah, I can cook.” Looking at her, I said, “What’s going on, you were acting all friendly just a few minutes ago. I thought we were becoming friends.”

“Why are you so quick to want to be friends?” stepping towards me, Caitlin said, “We just met yesterday, Amelia; I still need some time to figure out whether I like you or not.”

“You have a funny way of showing that then; inviting me to lunch and giving me a tour of the studio.” Taking a deep breath, trying to maintain my composure, I said, “Why’d you do all that if you didn’t want to be friends?”

“In my line of work, it pays to be on good terms with a talent agent.”

I was wounded; here I thought Caitlin was being nice, but she was only looking to use me. Looking at her, getting a little emotional, I said, “After our talk last night, I would’ve thought you’d realize I don’t like being used.” Taking a deep breath, I said, “I’ll see you when you get home.”

I turned to walk away; leaving Caitlin standing on the steps with a sad look on her face.

*******************************


After getting back to the house, I decided to get my unpacking finished. There wasn’t much left to do, so I was finished within a couple of hours. Once that was finished, I decided to unwind in the sunroom with my laptop and a glass of wine.

It took a few minutes to get the computer set up; but once that was done, I figured now would be a good time to send my family an email. After all, it had been 5 days since I’d left them, so they were probably waiting for me to reach out.

I logged into my new Gmail account and typed in Kelsey’s email address. Once that was done, I thought about what I would say; eventually settling on something short and sweet:

Hey Kelsey,
It’s me...
1111111113111111111111111111111111111111.title: Later On

1111111113111111111111111111111111111111.content:
I was halfheartedly reading some local news, 20 minutes later, when a message window popped up on my screen. It hadn’t occurred to me until then that communicating by email was my only option. Looking at the window, I saw it was from Kelsey.

Oh my God, I was beginning to think you’d forgotten about us.

It was the moment of truth; would I respond or ignore the message. I, of course, had no intention to simply ignore the message; so I took a deep breath and typed out my response.

Me – Sorry about that; as you might imagine, the last few days have been pretty crazy. How are things back in Jersey?

There was a short pause before Kelsey’s response appeared on the screen. Kelsey – You probably already know about it but Mom placed an obituary in the paper yesterday. We’ve been getting a lot of phone calls and visits from people; including people you probably wouldn’t have expected.

I couldn’t begin to imagine what Mom and Kelsey were going through; knowing that I wasn’t dead. Actually, in a sense, I guess I was – Kevin died on that hospital bed. That must be an awkward situation for you guys to be in; telling people I’m dead when I’m not.

Yeah it is, but it’s a price we’re willing to pay for you to be happy.

That response served to show how much my family loved me, and what they were willing to sacrifice for me. A stray tear rolled down my cheek as I started typing. There’s no way I’ll ever be able to repay you and mom for this.
